bboxes.raw_text:
Construction of the dam was
begun in 1903 and completed in
1911, at a cost of over 50 mil
lion, to the United States. In
1855, the original construction
cost plus interest was completely
repaid by the Salt River VAL
ley Water Users Association,
the governing body of the Salt
River Project.


Theodore Roosevelt, chief
sponsor of national reclamation
legislation and architect of the
1902 act, pers onally dedicated the
dam upon its completion on March
Is, 1911.


Theodore Roosevelt Dam Is
the world highest mas onry dam.
1t is 280 feet high; 723 feet long;
and 1874 feet thick at its base.


The lake behindthe dam covers
nearly 10000 surface acres and
has water storage capacity of
1881 $50 acre-feet.


A hydro generating station,
which has furnished electric pow
er to the Valley of the Sun since
1909, has installed capacity of
10000 hlowatts.


Registered National Land
marks are not administered by
the National Park Service, but
are recommended by the Advi-
sorry Board on National Parks,
Historic Sites, Buildings, and
Monuments from studies pre-
pared by the National Survey of
Historic Sites and Buildings. In
all of the United States, there
are only 452 such landmarks.

ATLANTA = Warming against
the danger of trying to solve
all civil rights problems by any
single method, NAACP Execu-
tive Secretary Roy Wilkins has
called for greater flexibility in
the fight for freedom.


No single method, the NAACP
leader said in an address here,
Jan. %, at the annual dinner of
the Southern Regional Council,
provides the answer to every
civil rights issue in all COM
mun1ties.


We must be prepared to "use
every technique, every tool avail
able. We need to devise new
tools. Our attack must be across
the board and must be leveled at
all forms and degrees of second
class citizenship" he said.


I'VE are engaged in compre-
hensive campaign for the civil
rights of 100000 citizens
scattered in so states, living
under varied economic, social
and political conditions and func-
tioning with variety of education
and technical knowledge, training
and skill.


1.-THE $4,000, 900 are minority
in l86.OOO,OOO citizens. Thus
even elementary reas oning would
seem to indicate that allies among
the majority must be won and held
If the minoritys efforts are not
to end in Illustration and failure"

WILKINS WARNS
AGAINST SINGLE
KIND OF METHOD

Health authorities warn - over
and over again! - that washing
hands before meals is the Number
One Rule for protecting health.
Whether meals are eaten at the
table or from a packed lunch box,
hands should be as clean as soap
and water can get them.


To make it easy for the lunch
box-toter, slip a damp, soaped
washcloth into a sandwich bag and
lay it just inside the box lid. And
add an extra paper napkin as
''towel."

Theodore Roosevelt Dam was
officially recognized on Few. 8 as
a Registered National Historic
Landmark in ceremonies held in
the Salt river Project Admins
tration Building.


The citation was awarded by the
United States Department of In
terror. Registered National His
toric Landmarks are areas or
sites which possess exceptional
value and are of national his
torical significance.


Mr.. Aubrey F. Houston, Sup
erintendent of Casa Grande Ma
tional Monument, presented a
certificate and bronze plaque to
members of the Boards Of Gov
errors and Directors of the Salt
River Project. Houston s presen-
tation was made in behalf Of the
Department of Interior and Ma
tional Park Service.


Victor l. Corbell, President
of the Salt River Project, re-
ceived the designation In behalf
of the Project officials.


Clifford A. Pugh, Phoenix Area
Engineer, was also on hand to
represent the u. S. Bureau of
Reclamation.


Located at the juncture of Ton
to Greek and the Salt River, 80
miles east of Phoenix, Theodore
Roosevelt Dam was the keystone
in the nation 8 first multi-pur-
pose reclamation project orga-
dzed under the National Recla-
nation Act of 1902. 1t is one of
seven dams in the Salt River Pro-
ject system.

MANFIASSET, N. Y. The
school board of this suburban
Long Island community an
nounced 1t would abide by court
order to desegregate the public
schools and would not appeal the
decision.


The board agreed to submit
plan for integration by April E
effective inSeptember as ordered
by Joseph C. Zavatt, chief Judge
of the US District Court, who
ruled on the NAACP suit On Jan.
"a. ..-1 -s.,.


In what may prove to be landr
mark decision, Judge Zavatt up
held the NAACP claim that de
facto school segregation in Man
hasset is unc constitutional. School
boards cannot use the excuse that
segregated schools are due to
neighborhood housing patterns
and are therefore, not theirrre
sponsibility, he said.


Judge Zavatts decision was
carefully spelled out in a 59-page
statement which probed deeply
into all the facts surrounding the
case. School boundary lines in
Manhasset have not been changed
since 1929 when the population
was predominantly white. Since
that time Negro migration into
the district had caused one of
the three elementary schools,
the Valley School, to become "a
per cent Negro with total atten-
dance of l66 pupils.


The other two elementary
schools, Plandome Road, which
has 900 pupils, and Munsey Park,
which has 574, are completely
white.

NEW YORK SCHOOL
DECISION UPHOLDS
PUPIL MOVING
